cleaned_text: For WaterISAC's Coronavirus Pandemic Member Crowdsourcing webpage (Members Only), [click here.](https://www.waterisac.org/portal/coronavirus-pandemic-member-crowdsourcing-updated-april-3-2020) This portal page is being updated regularly and is organized as follows: - Situation Updates (updated regularly) - CISA/FEMA Broad Stakeholder Call Information - Resources - COVID-19 Cases (numbers of cases in WaterISAC member countries and worldwide) - Return to Work Planning - Water and Wastewater Utility COVID-19 Impacts and Responses - Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) - General Workplace and Community Safety and Security - Cybersecurity - Business Continuity - Government Declarations Situation Update August 24, 2023 COVID-19 Activity on the Rise as Information about New Variants Emerges COVID-19 cases are again on the rise in the U.S., based on hospitalization data from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), which also forecasts more cases in the coming month. Yesterday, the CDC provided a risk assessment of a new COVID-19 variant, BA.2.86 (nicknamed "Pirola" by some), which it reports may be more capable of causing infection in people who have previously had COVID-19 or who have received COVID-19 vaccines. Meanwhile, the recently emerged EG.5 (also referred to as "Eris") is the dominant variant in the U.S., infecting more people than any other single strain. [According to CDC data](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_weeklyhospitaladmissions_7dayeddiagnosed_00), weekly new hospitalizations jumped 21.6% this past week, marking a fifth straight week of increasing admissions. The CDC also forecasts an acceleration in new COVID-19 hospitalizations over the coming month, with 1,100 to 7,500 daily COVID-19 hospital admissions likely on September 18. This replaces a previous projection that admissions would "remain stable or have an uncertain trend." [The CDC also reports](https://www.cdc.gov/respiratory-viruses/whats-new/covid-19-variant.html) it has detected the new COVID-19 variant BA.2.86, for which it released a risk assessment yesterday. Only two cases have been identified in the U.S. so far, but the variant is notable because it has multiple genetic differences from previous variants, potentially posing new challenges for immunity from prior infections and vaccinations. The CDC notes scientists are evaluating the effectiveness of the forthcoming, updated COVID-19 vaccine (expected to be released next month) but that its current assessment is the vaccine will be effective at reducing severe disease and hospitalization. Right now, the EG.5 variant, a descendent of the Omicron strain, is dominant in the U.S. It isn't setting off any alarms as far as disease severity, although early reports show it may be more transmissible. With these developments, the question is what precautions need to be taken. While far from previous peaks seen of the virus, the worsening trends translates to nearly 10 million Americans now living in areas the CDC deems to be at "medium" COVID-19 levels. For these places the CDC recommends people who are at high risk of severe disease wear a high quality mask when indoors in public. For the general public, it says Americans should consider self-testing and masking for contact with others who are at high risk. And of course, the CDC continues to urge people to get updated COVID-19 shots and stay home if they are sick. In some places, schools and businesses are responding by reinstating mask mandates, typically in situations where cases have been reported among students and employees. Read more at CBS News (articles [one](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-hospitalizations-spike-22-percent-cdc-predicts-increase-new-variants-2023/) and [two](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-mask-mandate-variants-cases-rising/)) and [Yale Medicine](https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/covid-eg5-eris-latest-coronavirus-strain). May 3, 2023 New Research Sheds Light on COVID-19 Variant Dynamics COVID-19 variants showed high diversity in their spread based on factors like vaccination rates, the number of co-circulating variants, and immunity from previous infections, according to new research recently published by a team from the Los Alamos National Laboratory. With COVID-19 still with us and the real risk of future pandemics, the researchers' work can help to inform modeling approaches that forecast how future variants and viruses may behave. The team looked at 16 COVID-19 variant transitions for 230 countries and regions from October 2020 to January 2023. They found variant transition dynamics differed substantially between locations and were associated with vaccination rates, prior infection rates, the time since the last COVID-19 peak, population demographics, and the number of co-circulating variants in competition with the emergent variant. Their research further demonstrated the effect vaccines had on the virus, noting they helped slow the speed of new variant transitions prior to the emergence of the Delta variant. However, continuing viral evolution contributed to new waves of disease spread, with viral variants that became progressively more infectious and resistant to protective antibodies, such as Omicron. The team also found stronger immunity acquired from prior infection, due to higher prior infection rates and a shorter time since the last COVID-19 peak, was associated with later and lower peak-prevalence variant transitions. This suggests that new variant transitions may be slower in locations with a large recent disease outbreak. There have been over 660 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 globally, leading to 6.7 million deaths. The virus continues to evolve, and global transitions to new variants can generate waves of disease spread, adding to the importance of the researchers' efforts. [Read more at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.](https://discover.lanl.gov/news/covid-variant/) February 2, 2023 White Houses Says COVID-19 Emergency Declarations Will End in May Earlier this week [the White House announced](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/SAP-H.R.-382-H.J.-Res.-7.pdf) it will end public health and national emergencies for COVID-19 on May 11 and noted the implications this will have on the nation's health system and government operations. The public health emergency (PHE) was set to expire on April 11 and the national emergency was scheduled to expire on March 1. The White House extended both to May 11, at which time both will end. It explained doing so is consistent with its plan of giving at least a 60-day notice before ending the PHE given the implications doing so will have. Given the emergency declarations provided additional funding to Medicaid and Medicare and the states, when they end access and costs associated with vaccines, tests, and treatments will be affected. For many, these services will continue to be provided through Medicaid and Medicare and private insurance, although there may now be costs involved. The White House's announcement comes at a transition time as the U.S. and the world move from a more acute phase of the pandemic to a more endemic spread pattern. On the same day as the White House's announcement, the World Health Organization (WHO) stated the situation still warrants a public health emergency of international concern, although it acknowledged the pandemic is at an "inflection point." Additionally, Dr. Ashish Jha, White House COVID-19 response coordinator, said there are other reasons for ending the two emergencies. He said the nation is in a better place with managing the virus and is getting through the winter without a big surge or a run on hospitals. He also said the nation has the tools for managing the virus. Read more at [the University of Minnesota Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy](https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/covid-19/biden-administration-wind-down-covid-emergencies-may) and [Time](https://time.com/6251520/covid-19-public-health-emergency-ends-what-changes/). January 5, 2023 Experts Tracking New COVID Variants That Could Drive Next U.S. Surge Scientists are investigating strains descended from COVID's Omicron variant to predict the shape of the next wave. Currently the variant families BQ and XBB are the most cause for concern, with XBB1.5 in particular spiking in number of infections at the start of 2023. This trend is due to two factors researchers believe could make the XBB family particularly resilient: high immune evasion and better ability to penetrate cells. XBB1.5 was found to be "49 times less likely to be neutralized" by antibodies compared to the most infectious COVID variants of summer 2022. A unique mutation also allows XBB1.5 to better enter cells, making it easier to transmit. However, while experts are concerned about XBB1.5's overall infectiousness, it does not appear to be any more severe than other COVID strains. [Read more at CNN.](https://www.cnn.com/2023/01/03/health/covid-variant-xbb-explainer/index.html) November 10, 2022 Wastewater Surveillance for Diseases Effective but Not Widespread, and Other COVID-19 Lessons Learned The RAND Corporation has published a report reflecting on lessons that can be learned from the COVID-19 pandemic so that the U.S. and nations worldwide can be better prepared for future scenarios. The report contains a collection of essays that explore topics of critical importance and identify actions that can be taken. In its second essay, regarding the role (and potential role) of government agencies in detecting and warning about an impending health crisis, the report comments on the advantage of using wastewater surveillance systems to get a near-real-time picture of disease spread. According to the report, public health officials in Houston and New York City used this technology to detect the Omicron variant 11 days before anyone in the U.S. tested positive for it. This system contrasts with the lagging indicators provided by looking at hospitalizations and deaths but unfortunately is not widespread throughout the U.S. Other essays in the report discuss lessons learned from Wuhan, China, where the coronavirus was first detected; reforming global pandemic preparedness and response institutions; meeting medical supply needs for future pandemics; and more. [Read the report at the RAND Corporation.](https://www.rand.org/pubs/perspectives/PEA1481-2.html) September 8, 2022 Updated COVID-19 Boosters Now Available; U.S. Plans to Shift to Annual Shots Following the CDC's and FDA's approvals of the updated COVID-19 booster shots last week, the federal government has been rolling out the new vaccines to locations around the country. When discussing the boosters earlier this week, White House coronavirus coordinator Ashish Jha said the expected cadence of delivering them in upcoming years would be similar to that of the annual flu shot, which could be administered at the same time. The updated booster shots, one by Moderna and another from Pfizer, are called "bivalent" and tailored to combat the two most prevalent omicron subvariants, BA.4 and BA.5, as well as the original strain. The previously approved vaccines were developed just for the original strain and demonstrated an inability to prevent reinfections and to trigger long-term protective immunity, prompting the need for the reformulated vaccines. In announcing the federal government's intent for annual COVID-19 boosters, Jha said staying up to date on vaccinations can get the country back "to a more normal set of rules," allowing businesses and schools to stay open. Heading into the third fall of the pandemic, Jha and other Biden administration health officials urged eligible Americans to get an updated booster. CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky cited modeling projections that were presented last week to the agency's vaccine advisory committee showing that if the public embraces the boosters early this fall at a rate similar to that of annual flu shots, about 100,000 hospitalizations and 9,000 deaths could be prevented. Read more at [PBS](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/health/updated-covid-19-booster-shots-are-now-available-heres-what-you-need-to-know) and the [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/09/06/covid-booster-shot-flu-pandemic/). August 25, 2022 Government Planning for Fall COVID-19 Booster Campaign with Updated Vaccines The Biden administration has signaled it will offer updated boosters to people ages 12 and older soon after Labor Day, according to media reporting. Updated shots from Pfizer and Moderna will target the BA.4 and BA.5 omicron subvariants, in addition to the original coronavirus strain, in a single shot. BA.5 is still the dominant subvariant, accounting for nearly 90 percent of all new COVID-19 cases in the U.S. according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Since the currently authorized vaccines only targeted the original strain of the virus, U.S. health officials are looking toward more finely-tuned boosters as a way to blunt possible surges in the fall as schools resume and as more people gather indoors. Both the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the CDC must authorize the updated boosters before they can be administered, but both authorizations are expected to be granted very quickly. If the authorizations happen based on the timeline discussed, vaccinations with the updated shots could begin as early as the day after the national holiday. Both Pfizer and Moderna noted they have rapidly scaled up manufacturing to be ready, if authorized, to deliver doses. Read more at [NBC News](https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/fda-plans-authorize-covid-omicron-boosters-labor-day-rcna44506) and [the University of Minnesota Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy](https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2022/08/moderna-files-emergency-use-ba4ba5-omicron-booster). August 16, 2022 CDC Streamlines COVID-19 Guidance Late last week the CDC released simplified COVID-19 guidance, detailing measures the public should take in terms of getting vaccinations and boosters and quarantining and self-isolating for positive cases and potential exposures. With this updated guidance, the CDC emphasizes the pandemic is not over but that the country is in a different place than before, with tools for reducing the severity of the disease and cutting the number of hospitalizations and deaths that translate into it not needing to severely disrupt daily lives. It promotes the importance of staying up to date with vaccinations, noting that the protection provided diminishes over time. One of the biggest changes is quarantine guidance for people exposed to the virus. Instead of quarantining, the CDC recommends wearing a high-quality mask, watching for symptoms for 10 days, and getting tested on the fifth day. People who are mildly sick with COVID-19 should still isolate for at least 5 days while wearing a high-quality mask. After isolating, people who are recovering should avoid contact with vulnerable people for 11 days. The CDC recommends longer isolation periods for people with moderate and severe illness. Another major change is that the CDC no longer recommends screening asymptomatic people who don't have known exposures. It urges people to consider their risks in particular settings, keeping in mind community transmission levels and ventilation, when gauging needed distancing measures. Read more at [the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2022/p0811-covid-guidance.html) and [the University of Minnesota Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy](https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2022/08/cdc-unveils-streamlined-covid-19-guidance). May 3, 2022 With Abundant Evolutionary Space to Explore, Coronavirus Threatens to Become More Contagious and Evade Vaccines The coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, has had billions of chances to reconfigure itself over the past 2 plus years, and it continues to evolve, changing its structure and chemistry in ways that confound efforts to bring it fully under control. In the early days of the pandemic, scientists were optimistic the virus would mutate slowly and that mutations would be inconsequential. In such a scenario, vaccines might not need regular updating. Not only did that prove to be overly optimist, but scientists now say the virus still has abundant evolutionary space to explore. This could enable the virus to evade vaccines as well as to become even more contagious than some of its subvariants already are. "This virus has probably got tricks we haven't seen yet," virologist Robert F. Garry of Tulane University said. "We know it's probably not quite as infectious as measles yet, but it's creeping up there, for sure." Case in point, preliminary research suggests the latest strain, BA.2.12.1, is 25 percent more transmissible than the BA.2 subvariant that is currently dominant nationally. Both emerged from the highly transmissible Omicron variant. The Omicron subvariants keep coming: scientists in South Africa have identified BA.4 and BA.5, which have mutations that were seen in earlier variants and are associated with immune evasion. In newly published research, the authors concluded these strains have the "potential to result in a new infection wave." [Read more at the Washington Post.](https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/05/01/coronavirus-more-mutations/) March 29, 2022 FDA Authorizes Second Booster for People 50 and Older and Immunocompromised Individuals; Omicron Subvariant BA.2 Becomes Dominant in the U.S. Today the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorized a second booster shot of the Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines for people 50 and older and immunocompromised individuals. The announcement comes as "BA.2," a more transmissible version of the Omicron variant, has become the dominant strain in the U.S. The second booster can be given at least four months after a first booster dose and is expected to become available immediately after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reaches a decision on who should get it. The CDC is expected to say people may get a fourth shot, instead of explicitly recommending they do so, a reflection of the ongoing debate about the benefits of additional doses and uncertainties about the future of the pandemic. But so far the federal government has emphasized the importance of older and immunocompromised persons getting the booster. "Current evidence suggests some waning of protection over time against serious outcomes from COVID-19 in older and immunocompromised individuals. Based on an analysis of emerging data, a second booster dose of either the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine could help increase protection levels for these higher-risk individuals," said Dr. Peter Marks, director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research. Evidence in support of a second booster is limited and mixed, based largely on data from Israel — where people 60 and older have been able to receive a second booster. Israeli studies have supported the idea that an additional shot could be lifesaving for people older than 60 but have also suggested the shots will have marginal benefits for young, healthy people and offer only short-term and modest protection against getting infected. Read more at [The Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/03/29/fda-authorizes-second-booster-shot/) and [NPR](https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2022/03/27/1089072803/the-fda-is-expected-to-authorize-2nd-boosters-for-people-50-and-up). The BA.2 strain now accounts for nearly 55 percent of new cases, based on [CDC data](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions) for the week ending March 26. That is up from about 27 percent two weeks earlier. BA.2 is thought to be about 30 percent more transmissible than the original Omicron strain, BA.1, which itself was already more contagious than earlier versions of the virus. Experts say there is no evidence that BA.2 causes more severe disease than the original Omicron strain or that it evades the protection from vaccines to a greater degree. "I can be pretty confident in saying that vaccines will continue to work really well at keeping people away from the hospital if they are boosted," said Dr. Peter Chin-Hong, an infectious-disease specialist at the University of California, San Francisco. When fully vaccinated and boosted, a person's cells adopt memory and are able to detect similar variants, preventing extreme illness if infected, he added. Read more at [The Hill](https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/600172-omicron-subvariant-ba2-now-dominant-strain-in-the-us-cdc?rl=1) and [The Wall Street Journal](https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-we-know-about-the-ba-2-omicron-variant-11643300997). March 8, 2022 COVID-19 Test to Treat Initiative Fact Sheet Today the Department of Health and Human Services published a fact sheet about the "Test to Treat" initiative that is included in the Biden Administration's [National COVID-19 Preparedness Plan](https://www.whitehouse.gov/covidplan/) that was announced last week. In this program, people will be able to get tested, and - if they are positive and treatments are appropriate for them - receive a prescription from a qualified health care provider, and have their prescription filled all in one location. These "One-Stop Test to Treat" locations will be available at hundreds of locations nationwide, including pharmacy-based clinics, federally qualified community health centers (FQHCs), and long-term care facilities. People will also continue to be able to be tested and treated by their own health care providers who can appropriately prescribe these oral antivirals at locations where they are being distributed. The antiviral pills include Pfizer's Paxlovid and Merck's Molnupiravir, which can help prevent severe illness and hospitalization when taken soon after symptom onset. HHS has already been distributing COVID-19 treatments, including oral antivirals, to states and territories for free on a weekly basis. Beginning yesterday (March 7), HHS also began distributing oral antiviral pills directly to participating Test to Treat pharmacy-based clinics, making more treatments available to more people in more locations. The fact sheet also includes a list of frequently asked questions about the initiative, such as where to find Test to Treat sites. It notes a federal Test to Treat website is in development with anticipated launch in mid-March. [Access the fact sheet at HHS.](https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2022/03/08/fact-sheet-biden-administration-launches-nationwide-test-treat-initiative-ensuring-rapid-on-spot-access-lifesaving-covid-treatments.html) March 3, 2022 White House Unveils New COVID-19 Plan Aimed at Returning Life to Normal Yesterday the White House unveiled a new road map for the COVID-19 pandemic, one that envisions life going back to normal while staying vigilant for new variants and outbreaks. There are four main goals in the 96-page plan: 1) protect and treat COVID-19, 2) prepare for new variants, 3) prevent business and school shutdowns, and 4) help vaccinate the rest of the world and save lives. The newest feature of the plan, which is covered in the first goal, is to offer a one-stop "test to treat" system at hundreds of pharmacies, community health centers and other sites starting in March — places where people can confirm whether they have COVID-19 and, if they're at high risk, get treated with antivirals on the spot, at no cost. As part of the second goal, the White House aims to give businesses guidance, tests, and supplies to stay open, including tools to improve ventilation and air filtration. It also notes the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) will update workplace guidance to better equip employers with the tools they need to ensure safe workplaces. The White House's plan also notes the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has updated its framework for recommendations on preventive measures like masking, so masks are recommended when and where they matter the most and Americans will be wearing masks less often. Read [the plan at the White House](https://www.whitehouse.gov/covidplan/) and [a relevant article at NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/03/02/1083905865/the-white-house-has-a-new-plan-for-covid-19-aimed-at-getting-things-back-to-norm). January 25, 2022 WHO Director General Warns Conditions Conducive for More COVID-19 Variants; Workers Share Attitudes about Workplace Safety Yesterday the World Health Organization (WHO) Director General warned conditions around the world remain conducive for the emergence of new COVID-19 variants, potentially tempering some of the optimism about the future of the pandemic as cases in some areas of the U.S. and other parts of the world have recently declined. Meanwhile, a new survey sheds light onto workers' attitudes about the safety of their workplaces, offering potential helpful information to leaders given that COVID-19, in some fashion, is expected to remain with us for some time. "It is dangerous to assume that Omicron will be the last variant, or that we are in the endgame," WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said at an executive board meeting. "On the contrary, globally the conditions are ideal for more variants to emerge." Striking an optimistic tone, he said it's possible to end the emergency phase of the pandemic this year if countries use tools and strategies known to drive down cases, including vaccination, increasing testing and sequencing, using targeted public health measures when needed, and using new solutions as they surface. In the U.S., one of the new solutions employed during the pandemic that has involved the sector is the testing of wastewater as an early indicator of COVID-19 prevalence in a community. Samples from wastewater taken from 83 US cities suggests the latest surge of COVID-19 cases caused by the Omicron variant may have already peaked in major urban areas. New York, Boston, Denver, Minneapolis and St. Paul, and San Diego have all likely peaked, according to the level of virus detected in sewage samples. Of all the measures, however, Tedros emphasized bridging the vaccine access gap across countries as a key step for ending the emergency phase. Read more at the University of Minnesota Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy ( [article Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2022/01/24/covid-omicron-variant-live-updates/). Given the likelihood that COVID-19 will remain with us for some time, even if the world ends the emergency phase, organizations must continue to factor in the virus for their workplace safety and resilience plans. One aspect of this is managing risks at the workplace for employees. To help inform discussions and decisions on this topic, Honeywell recently released the results of a comprehensive study on workers' perceptions and feelings on the health and safety of their workplace. The study surveyed 2,000 workers that typically work in buildings with 500 or more employees across the U.S., U.K., Germany, and the Middle East. The findings show that a staggering majority of the global workforce (68 percent) does not feel completely safe working in their employer's buildings. This number is even higher for those working remotely (75 percent), who are especially skeptical about the safety of work sites. In fact, nearly 1 in 4 remote workers (23 percent) would look for a new job rather than return to a site that did not implement necessary safety measures. January 18, 2022 Supreme Court Ruling Blocks OSHA Vaccine Mandate; Program for Ordering Free, Rapid COVID-19 Tests Begins Last week the U.S. Supreme Court blocked the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) vaccine-or-test mandate that would have applied to many American workplaces. This week, Americans can begin ordering free rapid COVID-19 tests online through a program recently announced by the Biden administration. The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 against the OSHA employer mandate, blocking it from taking effect while other legal challenges play out. Meanwhile, it allowed the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services vaccine mandate for health care workers to go into effect, by a 5-4 opinion. The cases now return to the courts of appeals for further proceedings, where it is very unlikely there will be a conclusion different than the Supreme Court's. Given a statement released following the Supreme Court's decision, it seems the White House recognizes the attempt to finalize the OSHA vaccine-or-test mandate is effectively blocked, noting "it is now up to States and individual employers" to institute vaccination requirements. The White House statement observed nearly one third of Fortune 100 companies had implemented such requirements. A limited number of places have adopted the equivalent of the federal rule for companies within their borders, such as Illinois and New York City. Outside of these places, requirements for workers at private companies from local and state officials are few and far between. And even states with plans to adopt the vaccine-or-test standard announced they would not move forward with the rule at this time. Meanwhile, almost a dozen states have adopted rules to prevent workplace vaccine mandates - from seeking to ban the mandates entirely or imposing specific restrictions on specific programs. Read more at [the American Hospital Association](https://www.aha.org/news/blog/2021-12-01-blog-updates-legal-challenges-cms-vaccine-mandate-rule), [The Hill](https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/589633-supreme-court-blocks-bidens-vaccine-or-test-mandate-for-employers?rl=1), and World Report](https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2022-01-14/states-and-companies-to-call-the-shots-on-vaccine-mandates-for-employees), and [Littler](https://www.littler.com/publication-press/publication/mandatory-employee-vaccines-coming-state-near-you). Officially beginning tomorrow, January 19, Americans can order free rapid COVID-19 tests online through COVIDTests.gov, part of a new program announced by the Biden administration in which the federal government is purchasing one billion tests. Each residential address is limited to four tests. Tests will usually ship within 7-12 days of ordering. Additionally, the White House announced a series of other steps intended to expand access to free testing, including by requiring private insurance companies to cover at-home COVID-19 tests, making more tests available at schools, standing up new federal testing sites, increasing the number of tests authorized in the U.S., and more. [Read more at the White House.](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/01/14/fact-sheet-the-biden-administration-to-begin-distributing-at-home-rapid-covid-19-tests-to-americans-for-free/) January 11, 2022 U.S. COVID-19 Hospitalizations Hit Record High, Hospitals Experience Critical Staffing Shortages, CDC Weighs Recommending Better Masks against Omicron The U.S. has surpassed its record for COVID-19 hospitalizations and nearly a quarter of hospitals are reporting critical staffing shortages due to workers being sick or off for quarantine. Meanwhile, the CDC is said to be weighing updating its mask guidance to recommend that people opt for the highly protective N95 or KN95 masks. Tuesday's total of 145,982 people in U.S. hospitals with COVID-19 passed the record of 142,273 set on January 14, 2021, during the previous peak of the pandemic in this country. More troubling still, those numbers are expected to continue to rise. Disease modelers are predicting total hospitalizations in the 275,000 to 300,000 range when the peak is reached, expected for later this month. The sheer number of cases has put pressure on hospitals, which are also contending with workers having to take off due to illnesses or quarantine requirements. Some facilities are leaving some beds empty, because they don't have enough staff to safety fill them with patients. Currently, about 24 percent of hospitals report critical staffing shortages, the highest of the pandemic, and many facilities are starting to limit elective surgeries and consider crisis standards of care. Read more at [the Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/01/10/covid-hospitalized-omicron/) and [the University of Minnesota Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy](https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2022/01/omicron-surge-sweeps-through-us-hospital-staff). With the highly transmissible Omicron variant spurring the current surge, the CDC is said to be weighing updating its mask guidance to recommend that people opt for the highly protective N95 or KN95 masks worn by health-care personnel, if they can do so consistently. Experts have recommended these masks vs. cloth coverings and have emphasized the importance of masking in general. The updated guidance is expected to say the best mask is one worn consistently and correctly and that if people can "tolerate wearing a KN95 or N95 mask all day, you should." [Read more at the Washington Post.](https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/01/10/cdc-weighs-n95-kn95-masks-guidance-omicron/) January 6, 2022 "Flurona" Co-infections of COVID-19 and Flu Reported in the U.S.; Supreme Court to Hear Arguments about OSHA Vaccine Mandate Tomorrow In COVID-19 pandemic updates, recent cases of "flurona" - when a person has both COVID-19 and the flu - have been reported in the U.S., and the U.S. Supreme Court is scheduled to hear oral arguments tomorrow on whether to allow OSHA's workplace vaccine mandate to go into effect. Some of the recent flurona cases in the U.S. have been reported in Houston and California, in cases involving children. Cases of flurona are actually not new, although the term was recently coined following infections in Israel. Instances of co-infection were reported in the U.S. almost two years ago. Additionally, flurona is not a distinct disease. But more cases of flurona could occur this winter as the highly contagious Omicron variant surges in the U.S., and around the world. According to Reuters reporting, the U.S. reported nearly 1 million new COVID-19 infections on Monday, the highest daily tally of any country in the world and nearly double the previous U.S. peak set a week ago. So what are the symptoms of flurona? Both COVID-19 and flu are respiratory infections, which can cause similar symptoms such as fever, coughing, fatigue, runny nose, sore throat and diarrhea, along with muscle and body aches. Both infections can be fatal, although the severity of each diagnosis depends largely on an individual's immune system. And for both, health experts and doctors stress that vaccines remain the best way to protect against severe infections. Given the emergence of the cases, as well as because it's flu season anyways, it's a good time to check the [CDC's information and guidance on the flu](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/index.htm). August 18, 2020 Researchers at the University of Southern California (USC) say they've found the symptoms of COVID-19 tend to appear in a specific order: fever, cough and muscle pain, then nausea and/or vomiting, then diarrhea. Knowing the order of COVID-19's symptoms may help patients seek care promptly or decide promptly to self-isolate, they researchers say. It also could help doctors rule out other illnesses or plan how to treat patients. The researchers' findings may prove useful for the upcoming flu season, helping medical professionals differentiate between cases of that illness and COVID-19. "This order is especially important to know when we have overlapping cycles of illnesses like the flu that coincide with infections of COVID-19," said USC Professor Peter Kuhn. "Doctors can determine what steps to take to care for the patient, and they may prevent the patient's condition from worsening." To discover the sequence, the USC researchers examined data from more than 55,000 confirmed cases in China, collected from February 16 to 24. And to compare the order of COVID-19 symptoms to flu, the researchers examined data from 2,470 cases in North America, Europe, and the Southern Hemisphere that were reported to health authorities from 1994 to 1998. Their findings were recently published in the journal [Frontiers in Public Health](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpubh.2020.00473/full). It can be transmitted through seemingly benign activities like speaking and breathing that produce respiratory bits of varying sizes that can disperse along air currents and potentially infect people nearby. This guidance is very similar to the Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers during COVID-19 Response recently published by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. [Interim guidance for COVID-19 safety practices for critical infrastructure workers](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/critical-workers/implementing-safety-practices.html)(CDC) - To ensure continuity of operations of essential functions, CDC advises that critical infrastructure workers may be permitted to continue work following potential exposure to COVID-19, provided they remain asymptomatic and additional precautions are implemented to protect them and the community. According to the CDC, in cases where workers have had an exposure but remain asymptomatic, they and their employers should engage in pre-screening, regular monitoring, wearing a face mask, social distancing, and workplace disinfecting and cleaning. As noted in its discussion of face masks, the CDC says employers can approve employees' supplied face coverings in the event of shortages (its ["Cloth Face Covers" webpage](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/diy-cloth-face-coverings.html)provides recommendations on how to make your own). The CDC states that an employee who becomes sick during their work shift should be sent home immediately and that the surfaces in their workplaces be cleaned and disinfected and a list of persons who had contact with the ill employee compiled. The CDC advises that this guidance should be implemented in conjunction with its previously published [Interim Guidance for Businesses and Employers to Plan and Respond to Coronavirus Disease 2019](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html). - Commercial Routing Assistance (CRA) tool (DHS CISA) - The U.S. Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and Idaho National Laboratory provided this tool, which may be useful to utilities whose employees include truckers or commercial drivers. Commercial Routing Assistance (CRA) tool merges coordinated and vetted data streams, plots multiple automated or custom routing options, and visualizes the wide variety of state regulations and actions that a driver would encounter along a route. With this free tool, commercial operators can plan vehicle movements across multiple states quickly, particularly during emergencies (a fact sheet is posted below as resource #29).
